content.user_title: Slack GIF Creator - Animated GIF Generator
content.value_statement: Generate custom animated GIFs optimized for Slack emojis and messages with automatic size optimization, frame composition, and smooth easing functions.
actual_capabilities: Create animated GIFs from programmatically generated frames using PIL/Pillow
Optimize GIFs for Slack's size and dimension requirements (128x128 for emojis, 480x480 for messages)
Apply smooth easing functions (ease-in/out, bounce, elastic, back) for natural motion
Draw shapes and graphics using PIL primitives (circles, polygons, stars, gradients)
Reduce file size through color quantization, frame deduplication, and global palettes
Validate GIFs against Slack requirements (dimensions, file size, frame count)
Implement common animation patterns (shake, pulse, bounce, spin, fade, slide, zoom, particle effects)
Create gradient backgrounds and composite visual elements
limitations: Does not include pre-built animation templates or ready-made graphics
Does not support emoji font rendering (relies on PIL drawing primitives)
Requires Python environment with Pillow, imageio, and numpy installed
Limited to 2D graphics and animations (no 3D rendering)
Frame generation is programmatic, not a GUI-based tool

best_practices: Start with 128x128 dimensions for emoji GIFs and 480x480 for message GIFs
Use 10-15 FPS for emoji GIFs to keep file sizes small (under 50 KB ideal)
Apply easing functions (ease_out, bounce_out) for more natural, polished motion
Limit color palette to 48-64 colors for emojis, 128 for message GIFs
Keep emoji animations under 2-3 seconds (12-30 frames) for faster loading
Use thicker outlines (width=2 or higher) for better visibility at small sizes
Test with validate_gif() before uploading to Slack
Enable remove_duplicates=True to eliminate redundant frames automatically
Layer multiple effects (pulse + rotate, bounce + fade) for more engaging animations
Use gradient backgrounds instead of solid colors for visual depth
anti_patterns: Don't create GIFs larger than 5 MB - Slack may reject or compress them poorly
Avoid thin lines (width=1) - they look choppy at emoji size
Don't use emoji fonts - they're unreliable across platforms and Slack clients
Don't create too many frames (>50) for emoji GIFs - file size explodes
Avoid linear motion without easing - it looks robotic and unpolished
Don't assume pre-packaged graphics exist in the skill - draw from scratch with PIL
Don't over-optimize - 48 colors is usually the sweet spot, going lower degrades quality noticeably
Avoid complex gradients or photographic content - they compress poorly in GIF format

faq.question: What's the ideal size for a Slack emoji GIF?
faq.answer: 128x128 pixels, 10-15 FPS, 48-64 colors, under 50 KB file size. This ensures fast loading and crisp display across all Slack clients.

faq.question: How do I reduce my GIF file size?
faq.answer: Use fewer frames (lower FPS or shorter duration), reduce colors (num_colors=48), enable remove_duplicates=True, use optimize_for_emoji=True, or reduce dimensions to 128x128.

faq.question: Can I use uploaded images in animations?
faq.answer: Yes! Load them with PIL (Image.open('file.png')) and animate them by transforming, cropping, or using as reference for drawing.

faq.question: What animation effects are available?
faq.answer: Shake, pulse, bounce, spin, fade, slide, zoom, particle bursts, and any combination. Use easing functions for smooth motion: linear, ease_in/out, bounce, elastic, back.

faq.question: How do I make graphics look polished, not basic?
faq.answer: Use thicker lines (width=2+), add gradients, layer shapes, use vibrant colors with contrast, apply easing functions, and combine multiple effects.

faq.question: Why is my GIF rejected by Slack?
faq.answer: Check dimensions (should be 128x128 for emoji), file size (ideally under 1 MB), and validate with is_slack_ready('file.gif') before uploading.

permissions: File system read/write access for saving GIFs
